facetValues.label: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies (Vancouver)
Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice (Vancouver)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: What is the role of culture in defining health for Asian Canadians? How do the experiences of Asian Canadians affect their health?Â

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: This course examines Asian/North American digital life as the shifting intersections between Asian racialization and information technologies. We will link questions about migration, new media networks, and digital selves to the ongoing projects of settler colonialism and empire. These inquiries will be illuminated through critical analyses of race, gender, and sexuality and by drawing from relevant fields of study, including critical race, new media, and Asian North American studies. In addition to reading scholarship from these fields, students will have the opportunity to engage films, TV, digital media, literature, music, and other cultural productions.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: ACAM350 â Asian Canadian Community Media offers an introduction to techniques and practices of digital media production within the context of ethical community engagement. Students enrolled in this course are expected to produce a short film on topics and issues pertinent to local Asian Canadian communities in Vancouver.Â  Through readings and discussions focusing on topics including race and representation, media and technology, oral history, deep listening, and the ethics of community-based research, this course encourages students to critically reflect on their participation in filmmaking as a tool for community engagement.Â  To showcase ACAM350âs teaching and learning outcomes, and to facilitate broader conversations around issues explored in student films, ACAM will host a public screening at the end of the term.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Online, asynchronous.

This is a core course for the Diploma in Education - Adult Learning & Education, the Diploma in Education - Health Education, the Adult Learning & Education UG Certificate Program, and the Arts Minor in Education - Community, Adult and Higher Education.

Registration will be blocked when the course is full and seats will be filled from the waitlist.

instances.text: AFST_V 309-201 - Arts of Africa and the African Diasporas

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Engaging with hands-on research based on the African collections of the UBC Museum of Anthropology, this course takes a comparative and historical approach to the arts of Africa and the African diasporas, exploring distinct formulations of what constitutes art in different parts of Africa and diasporic contexts. The course explores key debates that have framed the histories of African Art â tradition vs. innovation vs. authenticity; ethnic arts vs. national arts; art practices under colonial rule; modern African nations and national arts; international circulation of African arts and artists; markets, ownership, repatriation and reparation â and investigates their contemporary resonances.

For more information about African Studies courses, please visit this website: https://africanstudies.arts.ubc.ca/courses-2/2024-winter/

instances.text: ANTH_V 303-F_001 - Sounding it Out: Music and the Making of Diasporic Life (F)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Sounding it Out: Music and the Making of Diasporic Life Exploring the intersections of music and socio-cultural life in the negotiations of place and belonging in the African Diaspora. What is the place of music in the histories and formations of African diasporic consciousness and legibility? How do communities, through music, grapple with the afterlives of slavery and colonialism and create livingness in the face of multiple Â historical and contemporary challenges?

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Ethnography of the Mediterranean How do you think of the Mediterranean: vacation paradise, romantic destination, food mecca, cradle of Western civilization â or underdeveloped, conflict-riven area dominated by religion and violence? Come examine these conflicting portraits of the modern Mediterranean, an area in which many Canadians have cultural roots.Â While some anthropologists have treated the Mediterranean as a single culture area, others have emphasized its diversity, seeing it as a border in which many different cultures have historically come into contact, and, at times, conflict.Â  Thus one of the courseâs central questions will concern the nature and extent of the unity of the Mediterranean as constructed by both anthropologists and Mediterraneans themselves.Â Focusing on concepts such as honor and shame, hospitality, festivals and celebrations, gender, and conflict in the comparative study of Mediterranean cultures, we will explore the realities and representations of the peoples whose homes border on the Mediterranean Sea through a series of ethnographies, articles, films, and foods (yes, you read that right: get ready learn to cook and eat Med food!).Â 

Prof. Magliocco is an Italian native who has conducted fieldwork in and published on the Mediterranean since 1986.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Ethography of Australia This course introduces students to Australia as a site for rich anthropological inquiry. Students will engage with ethnographies of migration, Indigeneity, multiculturalism, social policies, race, and settler colonialism in Australia. Students will also learn about Australiaâs unique history as a site where liberal ideals of multiculturalism clash with the ongoing violence of racism and settler colonialism. Ethnographies of Australia will serve as lenses to understand broader anthropological debates on power, culture, and colonialism in the contemporary world.

instances.text: ANTH_V 303-I_001 - Archaeology of the Eastern Arctic (I)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Archaeology of the Eastern Arctic   This course introduces students to the study of ancient and historic societies in the North American Arctic and Greenland, with emphasis on Pre-Dorset and Dorset (Paleo-Inuit), ancestral Inuit (Thule), and historic Inuit peoples. Students will emerge from the course with an understanding of the regionâs culture history, how diverse societies emerged in challenging environments, and the analytical challenges specific to northern archaeological research. We will also consider emerging research directions in Arctic studies, including advancements in community-based participatory research, archaeological engagement with Inuit ways of knowing, ancient DNA and isotope analyses, climate change research, and the management of at-risk sites.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
NOTE: This is a multiaccess/hyflex course. There is a choice of attending in-person classroom lectures or joining class meetings via Zoom.

This course explores the central concepts and methodologies of anthropology of mediaâa sub-field within socio-cultural anthropology that explores the cultural dimensions of media production and consumption. While focusing on communication technologies (from newspapers, to photography, to social media), we broaden our scope to contemplate the expansive realm of media. We question the boundaries of what constitutes media and ask what else might be considered a medium. Through ethnographic examples, we learn how societies shape and are shaped by various media forms. Exploring media histories, theories, and methodologies, we scrutinize the essence of media, its workings, and anthropology's unique approach to its study.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Students in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems must register in the APBI 311 section, not the BIOL 364 section. 

Pre-reqs for APBI 311: Either one of BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. BIOL 204 pre-requisite is waived for APBI students.
